taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek sidus , star, and theke , case, alluding to starlike involucres]

bio:treatment.discussion: Sidotheca is allied to Eriogonum subg. Ganysma, approaching E. inerme in terms of foliar and overall habit. The trilobed to laciniate tepals resemble those of certain species of Chorizanthe. It is possible, as B. Ertter (1980) suggested, that the taxon was derived from Acanthoscyphus. In the 1950s, G. J. Goodman (1904–1999) proposed its recognition at generic rank, using the parahomonym “Neoxytheca.”

references.reference: Ertter, B. 1980. A revision of the genus Oxytheca (Polygonaceae). Brittonia 32: 70–102.

key_statement.description: Involucres funnelform, white-margined, bracts connate more than 3 / 4 their length; tepals 3–5-lobed apically, lobes laciniate
Involucres narrowly to broadly turbinate, concolored, bracts connate ca. 1 / 2 their length; tepals 3-lobed apically, lobes laciniate or not.
Perianths 1–2 mm, greenish yellow to red; tepals 3-lobed apically 1 / 5 their length; peduncles present or absent; awns of involucral bracts 0.3–1 mm; awns of inflorescence bracts 0.2–0.5 mm
Perianths 2.5–4 mm, white to pink; tepals 3-lobed apically 1 / 3 – 1 / 2 their length; peduncles present; awns of involucral bracts 0.3–2 mm; awns of inflorescence bracts 0.8–1 mm
